title: Astronaut omics and the impact of space on the human body at scale
background: Future multi-year crewed planetary missions will require advances in aerospace nutrition and telehealth, with increasing diversity of spaceflight participants and longer durations in harsh radiation environments beyond low-Earth orbit.
objective: Propose a Human Cell Space Atlas as an openly available global resource for space life science research and precision spaceflight healthcare, while addressing ethical, cultural, and legal challenges.
methods: Perspective analysis integrating current space omics initiatives, ethical frameworks, and technological capabilities for high-resolution molecular profiling in spaceflight environments.
results: Identified mitochondrial dysregulation as central to spaceflight impact, demonstrated pharmacogenomic variations affecting 24/78 ISS medications, and established international collaboration frameworks for space omics.
conclusion: Routine standardized omics collection could enable precision space healthcare and a Human Cell Space Atlas, but requires careful ethical and policy frameworks developed through international collaboration.

learning_notes.note: The NASA Twins Study revealed over 8600 differentially expressed genes between an astronaut who spent nearly one year on the ISS and his identical twin on Earth, demonstrating the profound molecular impact of long-duration spaceflight and establishing omics as a critical platform for understanding space biology and developing targeted countermeasures.

Pharmacogenomic analysis showed that 24 of the 78 standard medications permanently available on the ISS are significantly affected by individual genetic polymorphisms in drug-metabolizing enzymes like CYP450, highlighting the need for personalized pharmaceutical regimens during space missions to account for variations in drug metabolism efficiency among crew members.

International Standards for Space Omics Processing (ISSOP) represents a global consortium of space omics scientists from Japan, India, Middle East, Canada, Europe, Russia, and the United States, formed to establish standardized guidelines for the emerging discipline and promote communication exchange to maximize scientific discovery while minimizing ethical problems.

Liquid biopsies are proposed as a minimally invasive alternative to traditional tissue biopsies for spaceflight monitoring, allowing detection of cell-free components (microRNA, RNA, DNA, extracellular vesicles) in blood that can represent molecular responses from internal tissues and be obtained at repeated timepoints without compromising astronaut health or performance.

Spaceflight-associated neuro-ocular syndrome (SANS) affects over 20% of astronauts and shows associations with common variations in one-carbon metabolism genes combined with lower levels of vitamins B2, B6, and B9, suggesting precision nutritional interventions could help mitigate this unique spaceflight condition that has no known terrestrial analogue.

The proposed Human Cell Space Atlas would parallel the terrestrial Human Cell Atlas project using high-resolution omics technologies like single-cell RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics to create comprehensive reference maps of cellular responses to spaceflight, enabling better understanding of cell-cell interactions altered by space conditions and more precise countermeasure development.

Ethical considerations for astronaut omics data are amplified by the small, identifiable cohort of public figures, requiring careful balance between open science principles and privacy protection, with policies needing to navigate international laws and cultural differences while maximizing scientific utility and protecting against genetic discrimination and incidental findings.
